sp.p: I can't ſay that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: It is not a farthing matter.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington,
sp.p: Here is a mighty Riot upon the Hat.

sp.speaker: Mr. Weſton,
sp.p: Now I deſired them to keep back; my Lord Mayor's Friends did preſs back as much as they could to preſerve my Lord Mayor; they preſt more forward, as the other kept back, and I deſired them to forbear; nay, commanded them in the King's Name, and upon their Peril and took my Cane to ſtrike at ſome of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams,
sp.p: Did you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: He ſerved them well enough.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He did ſo. Do you think a Magiſtrate is to be crouded and preſt upon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Weſton,
sp.p: I ſtruck at them, and ſaid, Gentlemen, keep back, and entreated them and commanded them, and all would not do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: I would only ſay this, Mr. Com. Serjeant; What did you hear when Proclamation was made to depart?

sp.speaker: Mr. Com. Serj.
sp.p: My Lord, I was not in the Hall when Proclamation was made, but I heard them cry out, No God bleſs the King; and I heard them cry out, Down with the Sword; No Lord Mayor, no King.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams,
sp.p: Can you name any Perſon that ſaid this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Com. Serj.
sp.p: My Lord, I laid hold on one man that cryed, No God ſave the King; No Lord Mayor; and the Rabble got him from me, one that I heard ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams,
sp.p: Mr. Common Serjeant, you ſay, you heard this; can you name any perſon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Com. Serj.
sp.p: I tell you I caught hold of him, and the Rabble got him from me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams,
sp.p: Can you name any one?

sp.speaker: Mr. Com. Serj.
sp.p: I tell you I cannot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: My Lord, I hope that will not much prevail in this place, but I hope it doth juſtifie my Lord Mayor, for endeavouring to diſperſe the Rabble that came together to that height when the King was prayed for, to cry out, No King, No Lord Mayor. And we don't give this in Evidence againſt any one perſon, for it was done in a tumultuous manner; but they were ſo fond of this man, as that they reſcued him from him; and to fix it upon them, we will prove they were every one of them concerned in the Riot.—Mr. Craddock, What account can you give of this matter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Craddock,
sp.p: I was ſtanding at the place where they Poll'd, and my Lord Mayor was coming towards it to proteſt againſt their manner of proceeding; and Sheriff Bethel came to me, and ſaid, Reſiſt him, (I think) he hath nothing to do here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: That was Bethel, Slingsby Bethel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Craddock,
sp.p: It was either, oppoſe, or reſist him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: He ſays, he thinks he ſaid, Reſiſt him; but he is ſure it was either Oppoſe, or Reſiſt him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Jenks there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Craddock,
sp.p: I can't ſay I did: I ſaw Mr. Jenks juſt as My Lord Mayor came down, not after.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. John Deagle there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Craddock,
sp.p: I did not ſee Mr. Deagle.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How did they uſe my Lord Mayor?

sp.speaker: Mr. Craddock,
sp.p: I was not very near my Lord; my Lord, I ſtood at the place where the Poll was taking.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon,
sp.p: Mr. Craddock, We deſire to ask you this Queſtion, that you ſpeak particularly to Mr. Bethel, Was it before my Lord Mayor had Adjourn'd the Poll, or after?

sp.speaker: Mr. Craddock,
sp.p: It was juſt as my Lord Mayor came to Proteſt againſt the manner of Polling.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon,
sp.p: Was the Poll adjourn'd before or after?

sp.speaker: Mr. Craddock,
sp.p: It was after.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams,
sp.p: Mr. Bethel, you ſay, he ſaid, Oppoſe, or Reſiſt; did he ſay it before the Poll was adjourn'd?

sp.speaker: Mr. Craddock,
sp.p: Yes, Sir, it was before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams,
sp.p: Can you ſay what the words were?

sp.speaker: Mr. Craddock,
sp.p: It was either Oppoſe, or Reſist, he hath no Authority here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: Which is George Reeves? Mr. Reeves, Pray will you tell us what you did obſerve done at this time by Mr. Pilkington, or Mr. Shute, or any perſon elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Reeves,
sp.p: I came about 4 or 5 a Clock to the Polling-place where the Coaches uſe to ſtand, and I ſaw the Sword up, I ſuppoſe my Lord Mayor was there, and came to ſtop their Proceedings in Polling; and there was a great Conteſt among them; ſome ſaying, he had nothing to do there: He hath no more to do than I, ſays one; Another cryed, Stop the Sword, ſtop the Sword; and I laid hold of him, and got him a little way, and made account to have carried him to the Sheriffs, and the Lord Mayor, but ſome body got him away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Jefferies,
sp.p: What did you obſerve Shute and Pilkington do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Reeves,
sp.p: They encouraged the People to Poll.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones,
sp.p: After my Lord Mayor was gone?

sp.speaker: Mr. Reeves,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones,
sp.p: Pray you, Sir, did you obſerve either Mr. Shute, or Mr. Pilkington encourage the People to Hollow or Shout, or thoſe things?

sp.speaker: Mr. Reeves,
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: Heark you Friend Reeves, heark you; How do you know that Pilkington or Shute were Polling? Are you ſure they were Polling after my Lord was gone?

sp.speaker: Mr. Reeves,
sp.p: They were at the Polling-places, and they did not go away a great while after that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: From the People that were about them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Reeves,
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winnington,
sp.p: We agree it in Fact it was ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Richard Fletcher, Pray will you give the Court an account of what they did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: John Hill, What did you obſerve there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: About 5 a Clock, my Lord Mayor came to the Hall, there was with him then Sir James Edwards, and Sir William Pritchard, now Lord Mayor, to the beſt of my memory; and he told them he diſliked their Polling any more: and there came a tall black man; ſays he, Mr. Sheriff go on, it is your buſineſs, we will-ſtand by you; about a quarter of an Hour after my Lord came out of the Hall to the great Croud, ſome of the People hiſſing, and ſome making a noiſe; and one came to the Sheriffs, and ſays he, Gentleman, why do not you make Proclamation with O Yes, and they continued there till towards 8 a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: Did you hear no Officer Adjourn the Court?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: My Lord Mayor went home, I ſaw him within doors, and I came back again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was there no Proclamation made afterwards?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: By ſome of the Officers, but I did not take particular notice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Who did you ſee here after you went home with my Lord Mayor, and came back again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: I ſaw here Mr. Robert Key for one, and I ſaw Mr. Goodenough come in between 8 and 9 here in the Hall, and my Lord Gray came in, and ſeveral other Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did they do when they came?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: Heark you, Hill, Was my Lord Gray and Mr. Goodenough, and Mr. Key, were they among the People?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: After the Sheriffs came up, they went into the Orphan's Court, Mr. Goodenough came in and out, and my Lord Gray went in to them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: Did they appear among the People up and down in the Hall?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: They went through the Hall to and fro.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran. Winnington,
sp.p: What was the Chriſtian Name of that Goodenough?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: I know him, he that was Under-Sheriff laſt year: I know him well enough, and he knows me; yes, that is Mr. Goodenough.

sp.speaker: Lord Gray,
sp.p: I deſire to ask this Witneſs a Queſtion, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Let your Counſel ask, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: I deſire to know another Queſtion; Did you ſee Mr. Corniſh?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: I ſaw Mr. Alderman Corniſh walk in the Hall, but I can't tell whether he went into the Room, or no. After my Lord was gone, he did come up into the Mayor's Court, and came thorough among the People.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: Hill, you ſpeak of my Lord Gray; upon your Oath did you ſee my Lord Gray walk to and fro in the Hall, or only came thorough?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: My Lord Gray came in at that Gate, and went thorough the Hall, and went in to the Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams,
sp.p: I would ask you this upon your Oath, Did you ſee him do any thing more?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: No, I was there to diſcharge my Office.

sp.speaker: Lord Gray,
sp.p: My Lord, I own my being there; but only deſire to ask a Queſtion that will clear this matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: I ſaw my Lord Gray come up thoſe Stairs, and he went into the Orphan's Court.

sp.speaker: Mr Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: How long might that be after the Poll?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: After the Sheriffs came up I believe it might be half an Hour, or a quarter of an Hour, near an Hour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams,
sp.p: Did you ſee my Lord Gray do any thing more than walk?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: I ſaw him come to the Orphan's Court, and they would not open the Door at firſt; but they ſaid, it is my Lord Gray, and then they let him in.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Your own Councel is asking my Lord; I am willing you ſhould ask a Queſtion if your own Councel will let you. Gentlemen, my Lord would ask a Queſtion himſelf, and you won't let him.

sp.speaker: Lord Gray,
sp.p: My Lord, Though I do not know this Gentleman at all, yet I will venture to ask him a Queſtion: Pray Sir, did you ſee me ſpeak to any one man?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hill,
sp.p: I have anſwered that already, I ſay not.

sp.speaker: Lord Gray,
sp.p: Were the Books brought from the Polling-place by the Sheriffs before I came, before that I went in there? —My Lord, I was there, and ſhall give you an account of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It had been better, my Lord, if you had kept away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: Fletcher, pray will you tell my Lord and the Jury what you obſerved that day here after my Lord Mayor was gone and had adjourned the Court.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: On the 24th of June I was here by order of Sheriff Shute after my Lord Mayor had adjourned the Court, and it was to call all men that were to Poll to come forward, for the Books were to be ſhut up, and I went away immediately, I was very hot and went away to the Three-Tun Tavern.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Shute there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Mr. Pilkington was there and Mr. Shute too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Can you name any body elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: No, I can name no body elſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: What did Mr. Shute ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: He ordered me to make Proclamation for all men them that had a right to Poll, to come and poll, for the Books were to be ſhut up.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Captain Clark, pray will you give an account of what you obſerved?

sp.speaker: Capt. Clark.
sp.p: I came down into the Hall, and I did hear a whiſpering, whereupon I went to guard my Lord Mayor, my Lord Mayor came down upon the Huſtings, and Proclamation was made for the adjournment of the Court; whereupon when proclamation, God ſave the King, was made, an hundred, &c. I believe more, hiſt at that, I laid hold of one of them, No King's-man, no Sword's-man, cryed they; Sirrah, you are a Raſcal and a Traytor in your heart, ſaid I, and laid faſt hold on him; but there was a very great crowd, and ſayes one or two, For God's ſake Captain Clark, do you guard my Lord; There was Mr. Weſton and Major Kelſey; my Lord, ſaid they, is in danger; ſaid I, Gentlemen keep by him or go before, I will be in your Rear-Guard. My Lord Mayor was down upon his Knee, I can't tell how he came down, Preſs on, preſs on, this was the Cry, and God ſave the Sheriffs. After coming down the ſteps, I preſſed as near as I could to my Lord Mayor to keep them off; Now, ſaid I, this is the time to keep the Rabble off, now face about; I had my Sword in my hand, and with the pommel of my Sword kept them off; Before God, ſaid I, I will keep you off; and ſo I waited on my Lord home, and went and drank a glaſs of Sack. About an hour or two hours afterwards I came down to the Hall and found the People ſhouting, God ſave the Sheriffs, God ſave the Sheriffs; What nothing, ſaid I, of my Lord Mayor? But, ſaid I, this is not a place to quarrel in, let us not quarrel together. I ſaw the Sheriffs Pilkington and Shute were concerned in carrying on the Poll, and this they continued to do for ſome time, at laſt, I am weary of the Hall, ſaid I, I will go home; and this was between 8. and 9. a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Can you remember any body elſe beſides the Sheriffs?

sp.speaker: Capt. Clark.
sp.p: No, Sir, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Can you remember Sir. Thomas Player.

sp.speaker: Cap. Clark.
sp.p: No I can't

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies,
sp.p: Captain Clark, Did you know never a one of them that cryed out ſo?

sp.speaker: Capt. Clark.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I was before Sir Robert Clayton.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Major Kelſey, pray will you give my Lord and the Jury an Account of what you ſaw on Midſummer day.

sp.speaker: Major Kelſey.
sp.p:
My Lord, when my Lord came out of the Court I went after, and ſome cryed Stop him, ſtop him; but I got between them and ſome of my Lord's Friends kept them off; but when we came juſt to the going out, they gave a ſhout, and I ſaw my Lord Mayor's Hatt upon his Back.
and I can't tell whether he touched the ground with his hand, but I was e'en almoſt down; ſaid I, Gentlemen do you intend to murder my Lord Mayor?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Who did you ſee there?

sp.speaker: Major Kelſey.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I was almoſt down, and did not ſee their Faces.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Mr. Trice Hammon, I would only ask you, Who did you ſee, who did you obſerve to be there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p:
About 9. a clock at Night, or ſomething before, I ſtood at the Door that leads to the The ſame-place which before was called the Orphan's Court.
Common-Pleas, and there came in Alderman Corniſh and Good-enough, and Old Key, an old white-hair'd man, and by and by my Maſter Sheriff Shute came out and told me, I ſhall give you all Satisfaction by and by; God bleſs you, Mr. Sheriff, ſaid I; and he went again, and there I ſtaid till they came out, and then he went upon the Huſtings, and I went along with him when he came out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Who went with him out to go to the Huſtings?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p: Sir William Gulſton and ſeveral other men, there is never a name in the Indictment more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: None of them that are in the Indictment? name them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p: I have named them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Prethee name them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p: Mr. Alderman Corniſh, both the Sheriffs, my Lord Grey, Mr. Good-enough, and old Mr. Key.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: Which Good-enough?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p: That Mr. Good-enough that ſtands there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: There is ſuch a noiſe that I did not very well hear that word.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p: Goodenough, not that Goodenough that looks upon me, but he that ſtands behind.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: He falls behind now, but he ran up and down then, and Alderman Corniſh was there too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: You witneſs, you have named all theſe men, what did Shute do, or what did he ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p: When he came upon the Huſtings, he made proclamation himſelf, becauſe one or two refuſed it, he did it himſelf; and after a while he adjourned the Court upon the Huſtings; this was on Midſummer day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: What did he ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p: As the Common Cryer uſually ſayes at ſuch times.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: You ſay you ſaw Mr. Goodenough, and you ſaw my Lord Grey, upon your Oath, can you ſay they did any thing, or was any thing done in abuſe to my Lord Mayor?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p: They did not tell me, my Lord, what they did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: I ask you what did they do?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mighty buſie they were.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: How long was it after my Lord Mayor adjourned the Court?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p: About two hours.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: So much the worſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You muſt underſtand it was ſome time before Mr. Sheriff had made his adjournment, they were buſie till that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: My Lord, if your Lordſhip pleaſes, I do agree with Mr. Thomſon, that the Jury ſhould remember that this was two hours after my Lord Mayor had adjourned the Court.

sp.speaker: Lord Gray.
sp.p: I deſire, my Lord, I may ask him ſome Queſtions. You ſay you ſaw me go to the Council Chamber, at what time, and who went with me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p: A little before Candle-light.

sp.speaker: Lord Gray.
sp.p: You ſay all the Company went out with the Sheriffs, and went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammon.
sp.p: My Lord, I did not ſay you came out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord was of the Upper Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: Yes, and may be there again.

sp.speaker: Lord Gray.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall be there, Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: It had better you had been ſo then, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Gray.
sp.p: It will be the worſe for you, I ſhan't lie Perdue for you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: If you threaten me, my Lord, I ſhall take notice of it. My Lord, I have done you a kindneſs, but if you come under my hands again, I ſhall not do it.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice,
sp.p: They would not have it ſaid, God ſave the King, and my Lord you were with ſome of thoſe that abuſed him.

sp.speaker: Lord Gray.
sp.p: After it was over, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You were not within your duty here.

sp.speaker: Lord Gray.
sp.p: My Lord, it was after the Poll was cloſed.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire if you pleaſe, what is uſual in all cauſes, that we might go on without any interruption. Let us go on for the King, and then make all the defence you can. Don't think either to hiſs us or threaten us out of our cauſe. Mr. Higgins, give my Lord and the Jury an account of what you ſaw or heard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: My Lord, I attended with ſeveral of our Company by my Lord Mayor's Coach to Guild-hall, and was in the Council Chamber, and he ſent for the Sheriff, after that he went away; and when God ſave the King was ſaid, ſaid they, God ſave the Proteſtant Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: I deſire to know Mr. Higgins this, what they ſaid?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: They cryed, Down with the Sword.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney is making a Speech to us, I don't know what he hath ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: I don't think Mr. Attorney thinks you worth a Speech. Mr. Higgins, I deſire you to ask you a Queſtion, I ask you this Queſtion upon your Oath, after the adjournment of the Court, and after this very inſolent behaviour of ſome of the Rabble that were there, for I can call them no better, who did you ſee there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: After I went home, I went to ſee my Lord ſafe home, and came back again, I ſaw one Freeman that they call the Proteſtant Cheeſmonger, calling, To poll, to poll.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Pray who elſe did you ſee?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: I ſaw Mr. Alderman Corniſh come up towards the Sheriffs. Gentlemen, ſaid he, you are doing right.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Did you hear Mr. Alderman Corniſh ſay ſo? What this Gentleman? Do you know him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: Says he to Sheriff Shute, You ſhall have all right done to you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Who elſe did you ſee there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: I ſaw Mr. Swinnock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Key, did you ſee Mr. Pilkington?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: I did not ſee Mr. Pilkington, I ſaw Shute.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Jekyl?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Which of them do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: The Elder man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: There is John Jekyl the Elder, Gentlemen, and John Jekyl the Younger.

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: I was diſputing with a Fellow that his Toes came out of his Shooes, and had a green Apron, ſaid I, Are you a Livery man? Yes, I am, ſaid he. Surely, ſaid I, they don't uſe to make ſuch as you are Livery-men. Saies Mr. Jekyl, He may be as good a man as you, for ought I know. That was about half an hour after my Lord Mayor went home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: What time was the Adjournment?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: About 5. or 6. I was ſpeaking ſomething, You are all in a Riot. This is no Riot, ſaies Mr. Swinnock to me; I can never meet you but you are railing againſt the King's Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: The Kings Evidence, what was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What was done by Mr. Jekyl?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: He was talking among the People.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: He did encourage among the reſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: You are in a Paſſion now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: No Sir, I am not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: He ſeconded Mr. Corniſh when he ſaid, Inſiſt upon your Rights.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Who did ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: Freeman, my Lord, that they call the Proteſtant Cheeſemonger.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: A very pretty word indeed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Ay ſo it is, he is ſo called, you will give us leave to hear what the Witneſſes ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Another Epithet would do a great deal better.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: William Bell, what was done upon the ſpot, was there any hurt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Do you ſay, upon your Oath, that Gentleman was there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Higgins.
sp.p: I have ſeen him in the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: He ſaies he uſes to be there upon publick daies in the Coffee-houſe.—Bell, I would deſire to know of you, whether you are able to give an account after my Lord Mayor's Adjournment, who was there; name as many perſons as you can.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bell.
sp.p: Mr. Bethel, and I ſaw Mr. Corniſh go through the little Gate into the Yard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Who elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bell.
sp.p: That is all, Sir. Sheriff Pilkington delivered two Poll-Books into my hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Vavaſor, will you tell my Lord and the Jury what you ſaw?

sp.speaker: Mr. Vavaſor.
sp.p:
It happened thus, Mr. Hammond had taken a man upon Execution, who was Bail for a Client of mine who had paid the moneys long before; upon that I came to know who imployed him, and coming here, I found Mr. Hammond in that place, and the crowd was ſo great,
Don't go back again, ſaid he, for you will go near to be abuſed. Whilſt I ſtaid there, I asked him what was the meaning; Saies he, In this Room are the Sheriffs and ſome others caſting up the Poll; and whilſt I ſtaid, there came in Mr. Good-enough to and fro from them, and before they would admit any, they would know their names; there was Mr. Key, my Lord Gray, and Sir William Gulſton.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What afterwards?

sp.speaker: Mr. Vavaſor.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Corniſh was there, he and Sheriff Shute came out together, and they went upon thoſe Stairs under the Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Who came out with Sheriff Shute?

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What Corniſh?

sp.speaker: Mr. Vavaſor.
sp.p: Alderman Corniſh.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Very mannerly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: His name was Corniſh before he was an Alderman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Vavaſor.
sp.p: And Sheriff Shute told the People, If they would ſtay a little time, he would give them Satisfaction. Upon that, Mr. Corniſh went through the Company, and when they came to the Huſtings, Mr. Shute ordered Proclamation to be made, and told them, Whereas my Lord Mayor had taken upon him to adjourn at 9. a Clock, We the Sheriffs of London and Middleſex, being the proper Officers, do adjourn it to Tueſday at 9 of the Clock. Upon that an Antient Gentleman deſired they might proclaim the Election. Then ſaies Shute, that I can't do it now, for we have taken very good Counſel for what we do. Had it not been for Mr. Hammond, I had been, I believe, trod under foot ſufficiently.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Mr. Denham, who did you ſee?

sp.speaker: Mr. Denham.
sp.p: I ſaw Sir Thomas Player and Mr. Jenks.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Where did you ſee them pray?

sp.speaker: Mr. Denham.
sp.p: In the Yard. I went home with my Lord Mayor, and then I ſaw them. I had a kind of a glance, but I can't ſwear poſitively to Mr. Jekyl.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Player and Mr. Jenks, what did you ſee them do?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winnington.
sp.p: Heark you, Friend, where was it you ſaw them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Denham.
sp.p: In the Yard.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winnington.
sp.p: What did you ſee them do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Denham.
sp.p: Nothing at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: How many People might be there then? two or three hundred?

sp.speaker: Mr. Denham.
sp.p: Above a Thouſand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What did you hear Sir Thomas Player ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Denham.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: How far was he from his own Door?

sp.speaker: Mr. Denham.
sp.p: On t'other ſide the Hall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: A mighty way indeed, a mighty thing. What ſaid Mr: Jenks?

sp.speaker: Mr. Denham.
sp.p: I can't ſay, Sir, that I heard him ſpeak a word, only in the Tumult.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winnington.
sp.p: Friend, I ask you this, I think I heard you ſay you ſaw Sir Thomas Player and Mr. Jenks in the Yard; but you did not ſee them do any thing at all?

sp.speaker: Mr. Denham.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Farrington will you tell my Lord and the Jury what you ſaw after my Lord Mayor had adjourned the Court.

sp.speaker: Mr. Farrington.
sp.p: I ſaw there Sheriff Pilkington, Shute, Sir Thomas Player, Mr. Wickham the Scrivener in Loathbury, Mr. Jenks, Babington, one Jennings an Upholſterer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Player you ſay in the firſt place?

sp.speaker: Mr. Farrington.
sp.p: Yes, and Wickham, my Lord, a Scrivener in Loathbury.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Farrington.
sp.p: Sheriff Pilkington and Shute, and Mr. Corniſh, Alderman Corniſh.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Did you ſee one Deagle there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Farrington.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Wickham you ſaw there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Farrington.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, I know him very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: What is Wickham's Chriſtian Name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: John Wickham, he goes by that name, it may be he was not Chriſt'ned. Was Jenks there, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Farrington.
sp.p: The Linnen-Draper?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Ay, very well, he goes by the name of Francis Jenks. Did you ſee Jekyl there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Farrington.
sp.p: I don't know the name, I ſaw a great many I knew by ſight, but not their names.

sp.speaker: Mr. Holt.
sp.p: What did theſe Gentlemen do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Farrington.
sp.p: I'le tell you, Sir, there was Sheriff Pilkington and Sheriff Shute, I went in where they were taking the Poll; ſaid I, Gentlemen, my Lord Mayor hath adjourned the Court, what do you do here? I ſuppoſe it lies in my Lord Mayor's power; if it lies in him to call, certainly he muſt diſſolve.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: You argued thus?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Pray give us leave to go on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Farrington.
sp.p: There was Mr. Wickham, and ſaies he, My Lord Mayor hath nothing to do here, neither will we be ruled by any of your Tory Lord Mayors. This is not the firſt aſperſion, ſaid I, that you have caſt upon a Gentleman that loves the Church and the Government eſtabliſhed by Law; and they fell about me, and had it not been for Mr. Fletcher and Mr. Hill, I believe they had done me a miſchief; for they trod upon my Toes; who did it I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: But you ſay Sir Thomas Player and Pilkington and Alderman Corniſh were amongſt them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Farrington.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: That's enough.—Pray Mr. Cartwright, will you tell my Lord and the Jury what you obſerved there, and who was there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cartwright.
sp.p: I know the names of no perſons that were there, all that I can ſay was this. As ſoon as my Lord Mayor adjourned the Court upon the Hustings, he came down, and going out of the Hall, he had like to have been thrown down, had it not been for Mr. Shaw; and going to ſave my Lord Mayor, I wrenched my back, and I ſpit blood for ſeven daies after.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Tell that Mr. Cartwright over again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cartwright.
sp.p: My back was wrenched in ſaving my Lord Mayor, and I ſpit Blood 7 days after.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p:
Endeavouring to ſave my Lord Mayor his back was ſo wrenched that he ſpit blood 6 or 7 days after. Heark you Mr. Cartwright
ever ſince that time, have you found any indiſpoſition?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cartwright.
sp.p: I have not been my own man ſince.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: He took a Surfeit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: He took a Surfeit of ill Company I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Shaw, give my Lord and the Jury an account of what you know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Shaw.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord Mayor ſent to the Sheriffs, and ordered them to forbear Polling and come up to the Chamber, and ſent 2 or 3 times; but they denied coming to him, and went on and ordered the Common Cryer to make Proclamation for them to depart; and if they ſtayed that he would look upon them as Rioters; and there was hiſsing and a great deal of crowd, and there was Sir James Edwards in the Court, they hunched him with their Elbows, and as his Lordſhip came down going down the Steps there was ſuch a croud, that if I had not catched his Lordſhip in my arms he had fallen upon his forehead, and his hat was off.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who did you ſee ſo misbehave themſelves?

sp.speaker: Mr. Shaw.
sp.p: My Lord, I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: I think we have now proved it againſt every body we deſign, ſave only againſt Mr. Deagle, for we do not now proceed againſt Dorman Newman and Benjamin Alſop. Now, my Lord, we will only prove againſt John Deagle, and then we ſhall have done. Mr. Kemp will you tell my Lord and the Jury who you ſaw here. Did you obſerve any particulars after the Court was adjourned?

sp.speaker: Mr. Kemp.
sp.p: I don't remember I obſerved any one man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: You don't? Had you any diſcourſe with Mr. Deagle at any time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Kemp,
sp.p: Yes, I had.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: What did he tell you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Kemp.
sp.p: He did confeſs he was there about 7 a clock at Night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: He did own he was amongſt them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Kemp.
sp.p: Yes, with Alderman Corniſh.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: What ſay you, Mr. Rigby?

sp.speaker: Mr. Rigby.
sp.p: I ſaw him about 7 aclock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Was he in the crowd?

sp.speaker: Mr. Rigby.
sp.p: Yes, amongſt the People.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Here is all now, Gentlemen, but Dorman Newman, and Benjamin Alſop, and we don't go againſt them now. After they had done this, and hiſt at the King, and cried, No King, no Lord Mayor, what acclamations went theſe People off with?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammond.
sp.p: When the Court was broke up by the Sheriffs, they cryed, God ſave our true Proteſtant Sheriffs, and in that manner they followed us.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hammond.
sp.p: They hollowed us home, Sir, as far as fiſhmonger's Hall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: They began with a hiſs, and ended with a hollow.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I am Councel for the Defendants, and my Lord, the queſtion is under favour, Whether theſe perſons taken for Defendants, whether they be guility of this Riot, as it is laid in the Information. We are now upon as ſpecial Caſe, and the queſtion is, Whether guilty, or not guilty. My Lord, in the firſt place for the Cries, what the Cry was, hath been too often mentioned; for thoſe Cries there is nothing at all fixt
upon any perſon that is Defendant; all that is charged upon us, is, That we were in the Hall it ſeems, and becauſe there was this noiſe heard, therefore we muſt be guilty. In this crowd where we are, I hear hiſſing, eſpecially at to'ther end of the Hall, which of us are concerned in it, is a hard matter to judge; it is a hard matter, and it were very well, and it had been very happy, if ſome of thoſe perſons, had been apprehended for their hiſſing. I won't ſay, Gentlemen, that either one party or to'ther in the Conteſt made the noiſe of hiſſing, but there is nothing of it fixt upon any of us. Our Caſe is this, my Lord, with favour, when we have ſtated our Caſe and proved it, we are very innocent, and not guilty of the Riot. In ſome meaſure it hath been ſtated on the other ſide. They ſay in the Information, that the Lord Mayor called a Common-Hall; we don't diſpute that matter, we agree it, that the Lord Mayor of London is the Kings Lieutenant but to make ſuch and inference, That becauſe the Lord Mayor is the King's Lieutenant in the City of London, that he muſt execute all the Offices in the City, is of no credit in the world; ſo that they are miſtaken in that. Men are bounded in their Offices. The Lord Mayor does not execute all the Offices in the City though he be Lord Mayor. The queſtion between us is this, Whether the Sheriffs, in this caſe did more than their Office as Sheriffs of the City of London. There is a ſuperiority due to the Lord Mayor. Another thing we agree with them, we agree it is in the Lord Mayor only to call theſe Com-mon-Halls, and as Mr. Serjeant Jefferies, that hath been in a good Office in the City, he agrees it himſelf, and it is apparent, there are ſome fixt days for Election; but yet though there be fixt days for Election, yet there muſt be that Formality of a Summons from the Lord Mayor to the City to meet in order to the Election of Sheriffs for the City of London and other Officers, that we do agree that my Lord Mayor hath the Power of calling Common-Halls, and he is the proper Officer. We agree alſo, Gentlemen, that when the buſineſs is done, for there is nothing in vain in nature, and there is nothing in Government that ſhould be in vain, when the buſineſs is done, my Lord Mayor is to bid the Company Fare them well, which you may call diſcharging the Common-Hall; we agree that to be commonly and uſually done by my Lord Mayor. But herein we differ, which we are to try, the right of the Office of Sheriffs being the queſtion, it is a queſtion of right, and I don't ſee the Government is concerned one way or other.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Upon my word I do ſee it, and ſurely you muſt be blind, or elſe you would ſee it too, when a company is got together, no God ſave the King, No King, no Lord Mayor.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p:
My Lord, I thought I had opened it plainly, I ſpeak before a great many people, I deſire, my Lord, this may be very well heard. I thought I had ſaid very well, from all theſe Noiſes and Cries we are all innocent, we juſtifie nothing of it, only we would have been glad if they had apprehended any man that made that noiſe; it had been a very happy thing if one of them, or all of them had been Defendants to be tryed. My Clients are Defendants, they are innocent and unconcern'd, it is a Crime committed by ſome where theſe Gentlemen were by, but they are innocent; we hear hiſsing at t'other end of the Room, it was an ill thing, and of a Treaſonable complexion; but for theſe Gentlemen they are unconcern'd. The Queſtion between the Lord Mayor and the Sheriffs of the City, is a Queſtion of Right between the Mayor and Sheriffs, Whether it be the Prerogative of the Mayor, or the Right of the Sheriffs? and I ſay,
under correction again, this Queſtion, Whether the Lord Mayor of London may adjourn the Common-Hall to a certain day, is a queſtion of Right Whether he can do it or the Sheriffs; And I don't ſee what conſequence it can have upon the Government. The Lord Mayor is the King's Deputy, the Sheriffs they are the King's Officers, and the Queſtion is, Whether it be in the Lord Mayor or the Sheriffs of London to adjourn it? They are very good Subjects, I am ſure this very Year they are ſo; therefore I wonder at theſe Gentlemen of the King's Counſel, that will meddle with the Government, and ſay the Government is concerned in this; I appeal to any man if there be any more concern in this. I ſay this, here was a Common-Hall call'd, grounded upon Cuſtome in the City of London, and here is a ſingle Queſtion, Whether theſe Sheriffs did any more than their duty; whether they were guilty of a Riot in continuing this Poll. Gentlemen, this is the method we ſhall take. Firſt of all, it is not proved, that ever the Lord Mayor before this time did ever attempt to adjourn a Common-Hall to any certain time; all the Witneſſes that were call'd, that pretend to be knowing in the Cuſtomes of London, the Common Serjeant himſelf, he does not pretend that it was adjourn'd to a day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: You miſtake. Sir Robert Clayton did from Saturday to Munday.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What need if there had been no Preſident; if ſo be an Aſembly of People are met about buſineſs, and they can't make an end of it in a reaſonable time, muſt they be kept all Night till they have? What Argument will you make of it? If a man may call and diſſolve, do you think if there be occaſion, but, by the Law it ſelf, that he may adjourn to a convenient hour?

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: That will be a queſtion between us. My Lord, what I ſay certainly of Fact carries ſomething in it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, I have done.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Give us leave to underſtand ſomething, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winnington.
sp.p: My Lord, by your Lordſhips favour—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I ſpake to Mr. Williams, and he takes it ſo hainouſly at my hand that Facts ſignifie nothing; I do again ſay it, The fact ſignifies nothing. For I tell you again as Law, it is not denied the Lord Mayor may call, he may diſſolve; then I ſay by Law, without Fact, by Cuſtom, he that can both call and diſſolve, may adjourn to a convenient time. Do not Judges of Aſſize in all the Counties of England do it, when a Cauſe is appointed to be tryed in ſuch a County ſuch a day, and it may be it is tryed 3 daies after; and yet I pray find me the Statute or Commiſſion, or find me one thing or another beſides the very Law it ſelf, that doth give them leave to adjourn from time to time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p:
My Lord, there is a mighty difference, but I am only upon fact, theſe Gentlemen will agree it was never practiced before Sir
Robert Clayton's time, what the conſequence in Law will be, that is in your Lordſhips Breaſt, I am now ſpeaking upon the Evidence that this hath not been practiced. What the Law is, for that we are to have your Judgment, which I humbly crave, I will be judged by Gentlemen that are my Seniors and better read in this matter; but, my Lord, a man may have a power of calling and diſſolving, and not of adjourning, it may be ſo. But, my Lord, admitting it to be ſo for this time, yet, my Lord, whether we are guilty of a Riot, take the Circumſtances of our Caſe. Whether the Right of adjourning be in the Sheriffs, yea, or nay, it is a queſtion of Right, and I had rather apply my ſelf to your Lordſhip than to the Jury. If there were a Queſtion of Right between the Lord Mayor and the Sheriffs, it may be admitted by our Councel that it was his Right to adjourn the Court, and probably the Sheriffs might be in the wrong, and the Lord Mayor in the right. The Lord Mayor adjourns the Court, and they continue it, they go on with the Poll, and go on with the execution of their Office as they apprehended, if they were ſtill for their Right, I hope your Lordſhip will not make this a Riot. My Lord, for the Circumſtances that followed, the noiſe that was made, which I don't love to mention, if, I ſay, they were guilty of this, I am ſilent; but if they did no more, as I hear no more proved upon them, then continuing the Poll, then, I ſay, it will be very hard to make them guilty of the Riot. And another thing is this, my Lord, we all know, if there were a thouſand Electors, any man knows, that when there is a queſtion upon an Election, it is impoſſible ſuch a thing ſhall be carried on but there will be reviling, ill language, and the like; and to turn all theſe things to a Riot, a thing ſo common from the beginning of Elections to this time, if there be diviſion and polling, there will be ſomething you may turn to a Riot. But I ſay this, they have not inſtanced in any one Defendant, that he was guilty of any one particular act that amounted to a Riot in it ſelf, they have not inſtanced in one. They ſay of Alderman Corniſh, That he was of the ſame opinion with the Sheriffs, that they did inſiſt upon the Rights of the City, he took it to be the Right of the Sheriffs; And, ſaies one of them, I will ſtand upon it, Bethell that had been Sheriff. Now we will call our Witneſſes, we will prove what hath been the conſtant practice in the City, we will prove the methods of adjournment; and, my Lord, this is to be ſaid which your Lordſhip will obſerve, That the Sheriffs adjourned the Court to the very ſame time with my Lord Mayor; ſo that it was no more than to bring the matter to an iſſue in this caſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winnington.
sp.p:
Spare me a word in this caſe, my Lord. There is no Evidence produced againſt Trenchard, nor againſt Jekyl the Younger, nor againſt Bifield, nor 〈…〉 of theſe there is no queſtion but they are as if they were out of the Information, I muſt beg leave for a word or two as to thoſe Defendants, that they have offered ſome Evidence againſt. The queſtion is now before your Lordſhip, Whether they are guilty of a Riot or no? My Lord, for ought I ſee, it will ſtand upon a nicety of Judgment; yet if there be not matter enough, Gentlemen, to make the Defendants guilty of a Riot, then it will clear the Defendants. My Lord, as to thoſe words, that really were words that ought to be inquired into, who they were that ſpoke them in relation to his Majeſty; I think it was a very ill thing of thoſe
men that ſaw them, that they would not neglect all manner of buſineſs to ſeize them, I think it was a duty to fix upon them: but, my Lord, there is no Evidence to put it upon any of the Defendants. My Lord, that being pared off, now the queſtion is, That the meeting together was lawful, that is agreed; then when they came together, my Lord, I do think that if we do rely upon the Evidence, it will be a mighty hard thing to make this a Riot, ſetting aſide thoſe villainous words that were ſpoken, which cannot relate to the Defendants. Suppoſe, my Lord, that among the Electors, the whole Common-Hall of the City, there doth a diſpute ariſe before the Election is over concerning the adjournment of the Sheriffs or the Lord Mayor, ſome men are of one opinion, ſome are of another; and their Evidence, Mr. Peter King and another, Attorneys, I asked the queſtion ſeveral times, Did the Lord Mayor of London, ever interpoſe or concern himſelf in adjourning the Hall, till the Election was quite finiſhed? and they ſaid No; Then, my Lord, I muſt ſay it as to theſe particular Defendants, in ſuch a concourſe of People as was met there, it is as ſlender a proof of a Riot as ever was, and intimates that the Citizens of London, they that happen not to be the greater number, they that loſe the Election, may be found guilty of a Riot in chuſing other Officers as well as in the buſineſs of Sheriffs; which being ſo tender a point, I think it will be a very ſevere expoſition, my Lord, to make this a Riot. But now for the Matter, we will call to your Lordſhip ſeveral Witneſſes, men that have been Magiſtrates in the City, that it was alwaies looked upon, that my Lord Mayor, as he is the Principal Magiſtrate, he gives notice for Common-Halls; and when the ſeveral Electors are met, and the buſineſs is over, he directs them to go home, and diſſolves them; but my Lord Mayor meddles not in every little adminiſtration of the Election of Officers, but leaves them to inferiour Officers, the Sheriffs and others, that is their duty, my Lord, with ſubmiſſion, they Poll them and ſend them home during the Election, therefore by Law they do this; for, my Lord, the Cuſtome of a City, and the Cuſtome of a Place, is the Law of the place; and if the Cuſtome of the place hath been, that the Sheriffs have been the perſons that have managed it, it is their Right; but the Common Serjeant he ſaies he hath the ſole management of it; Then if it be as Mr. Common Serjeant ſaies, if that muſt go, upon my word, Gentlemen, your Priviledges are reduced to a little compaſs.—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: They did conferr one with another who they took to have the moſt Voices, and ſo reported it, not that he did claim any thing in his own right, but as an Officer of the City. Now it is plain, and I think there is no inconveniency falls upon it, if an Officer acquaints my Lord Mayor, according to the beſt of our Judgment we think ſuch a man hath the moſt Voices, that does not give him a right for him to make an Officer, not at all.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr. Winnington.
sp.p:
I ſay what he ſaid in his Evidence, but one of the Attornies ſwears that they have all equal power, I wonder then who ſhould make an end of the buſineſs. My Lord, we will call to your Lordſhip Ancient Citizens, that have been frequent at Elections, to give you an account that the Sheriffs always had the management, that my Lord Mayor never concerned himſelf, till he had notice it was determined;
and if that be ſo, and the practice hath been ſo, then I don't ſee under favour my Lord, how they will make this a Riot; that is the Caſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: Sir. Robert Clayton, will you pleaſe to tell my Lord and the Jury in what manner the Election of Sheriffs hath been, and how the Mayors have uſually left it to the Sheriffs in that caſe.

sp.speaker: Sir. Robert Clayton.
sp.p: My Lord, I have never heard this matter hath been in queſtion till of late, ſo I cannot declare much upon my own knowledge how the truth of fact is or ſhould be, I can only ſay this, what the practice hath been. When I came to the Chair I did endeavour to know my duty and to do it. The firſt time I had occaſion to take notice of this matter was in the year of my Mayoralty, I did then accoding to cuſtom Summon a Common-Hall, when I had ſummon'd it, there was a perſon preſented to the Hall I had drank to; the Hall did refuſe him, and there was a great noiſe and hubbub upon it, and we found a way to accomodate that matter, and left them to chuſe two Sheriffs for themſelves. I retired into this Court together with my Brethren and Mr. Recorder, that was then, We ſent for the Sheriffs up to examine the matter, they told us that they could not agree the thing, there was 4 Perſons in Nomination, but they had granted a Poll. After this we went down into the Hall, of that Mr. Common Serjeant hath given ſome account, and Mr. Serjeant Jefferies, I ſhall to the beſt of my memory give the beſt account I can of it, I ſhall only tell you what I did underſtand to be my duty, I do not determine what the practice was, but what I underſtood to be my duty. When we came down into the Common-Hall to declare how the matter ſtood, and that a Poll was agreed upon and granted, we would have adjourned the Court to a longer time, but the people cryed out to go to the Poll preſently. I was, as you have been told by Mr. Common Serjeant, to go to the Tryal of one Giles upon the Aſſaſſination of Arnold, to the Old Baily. I did twice or thrice attempt to get down out of the Hall through the crowd, and was repulſt, the croud was ſo great I could not get through, but was fain to retire back again to the Hustings as I remember two or three times. There might be ſome ſuch diſcourſe as Mr. Common Serjeant hath ſaid, but thus far I can remember, that I did both by my ſelf and the Common Serjeant ſignify to them the buſineſs I was about, and ſo many Aldermen as made up a Bench together with Mr. Recorder to manage that buſineſs, muſt go, and that I would leave the Sheriffs to manage the Poll, which I thought was their duty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: Did you take it to be their right?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Clayton.
sp.p: I did not apprehend it to be my right then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: And therefore you left it to the Sheriffs as their right.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Clayton.
sp.p: I left it to the Sheriffs to manage the ſame.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Sir Robert Clayton, I ſuppoſe when you were Lord Mayor you were as much for the honour of the Chair as any man, you would not have quitted the right of the Chair.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: I did not, there was a Trial of me in that caſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Now Sir, for adjourning the Poll, did you know any ſuch queſtion whether a Poll was to be adjourn'd upon the Election of any Sheriffs?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: There hath been a great noiſe about adjournments of late. That Poll was the moſt litigious of any that I know we have had before or ſince, that was adjourn'd for ſeveral days.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Who adjourn'd that Poll?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: The Sheriffs did adjourn it I think. Gentlemen, I do think the Sheriffs did adjourn it, I was not preſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Sir Robert, don't ſerve the Court thus.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Don't brow-beat our Witneſſes, Gentlemen. I know, Mr. Attorney, you are an example of fair practice: We are examining our Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, let me explain my ſelf, I ſhall let Mr. Attorney General underſtand me. I did never appear at Guild-hall, unleſs upon the account of a Court of Aldermen I did never appear at Guild-hall, but the firſt day we had Conſultations here in this Court about the adjournment, and upon the Huſtings about going about the buſineſs we intended, and the Hall was very intent upon the Poll; I twice attempted to go out, and could not get out, whereupon we were fain to acquaint the Hall as well as we could for the noiſe, of the buſineſs we were to go about, and they let me go. I left behind the Sheriffs and the Common Serjeant; how long they ſtayed I can't tell, I can upon my own knowledge give no account of them. I was not conſulted to the beſt of my knowledge afterwards, nor did give any particular directions for adjournment. I did not do it for this reaſon, I did not look upon it to be in my power: if I had ſuch a power, I did not underſtand it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Sir Robert, how many days do you think that Poll continued?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: About ſix days.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Of thoſe ſix how many days were you preſent?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: I did not underſtand it to be my duty, and ſo did not look after it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: Sir Robert Clayton, I deſire to ask you a queſtion, as to this matter you have given in evidence; do you give it to the beſt of your remembrance or poſitively?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: I tell you I ſpeak to the beſt of my remembrance every thing that I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Sir Robert Clayton, I beg your favour, to the beſt of your remembrance is no evidence, it is ſo lately; if you pleaſe, Sir Robert, you are to give evidence of a thing about three years ago. I ask you upon your Oath who were your Sheriffs?

sp.speaker: Sir. R. Clayton.
sp.p: Sir Jonathan Raymond and Sir Simon Lewis.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I would ask you then a plain queſtion. Sir Robert, becauſe you come in with your remembrance; did you give expreſs direction to the Common Serjeant or the Sheriffs to adjourn upon your oath?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: I muſt, Mr. Attorney General, by your favour take in my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then you are no evidence. Sir Robert, did you give directions or not, upon your oath?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: I can't ſay it was given.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you, or did you not?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: My Lord, I hope I have ſpoke Engliſh in the caſe, we did diſcourſe of the Adjournment in this Court, I believe it was diſcours'd below; but as I ſaid I was engaged to go to the Old Bayley, and I would leave that matter to the Sheriffs, whoſe proper buſineſs I underſtood it to be.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I ask you Sir Robert, one of the plaineſt queſtions that ever was asked; I ask you whether you gave the Sheriffs or the Common Serjeant expreſs order to adjourn?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: I believe I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did the Sheriffs tell you they had a right then?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: There was no diſpute who had the right.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Sir Robert Clayton, if you pleaſe I would ask you a queſtion or two. Do you remember that the Court was adjourn'd while you were there or not? Do you underſtand the Queſtion, Sir Robert? Do you remember the Common Hall was adjourned while you were there.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, If you give me leave to explain my ſelf, I think the Common Hall was adjourn'd; it was declared, but there was ſuch a noiſe in the Hall that the people could not hear it.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: But there was a ſort of Declaration made by your ſelf, you did make an adjournment; but the noiſe was ſuch that the people did not hear: and if you remember, there was a perſon affronted one of the Sheriffs, and I committed him to cuſtody upon it.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: We deſired to adjourn for an hour or two, that we might go and refreſh our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Then you remember there was an adjournment. I ask you whether it was appointed to be made by you or the Sheriffs?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: Truly I believe it was appointed by me.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Sir Robert, by asking you a queſtion or two, Sir Robert, I know I ſhall bring ſome things to your remembrance.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: My Lord, I don't know I have given any great occaſion of Laughter to my Brethren; theſe Adjournments have been very common with us, and I might agree to it or order it or direct it, but one of them I believe I did, or two of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Sir Robert, I would only have a queſtion or two asked, and I know by asking a queſtion or two I ſhall bring things to your memory, which I am ſure you cannot eaſily forget: Were there directions given for Proclamation to be made for all Parties to depart in the King's name?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: I believe there might.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: The next queſtion is, whether the Sheriffs ordered that Proclamation to be made for all Parties to depart?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: If it were done while I was preſent, I make no doubt in the caſe, but I did direct it, I make no queſtion of that.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Very well now, Sir Robert Clayton, we are got to an adjournment to a time by your direction, and proclamation by your direction. Now I will ask another queſtion upon your oath; was not you in the Common Hall and gave order for an adjournment till Monday following, for I remember that day to be Saturday?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: Truly I do not remember that.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p:
You do not? Sir Robert, you know very well, that the Sheriffs of London, when the Lord Mayor and Aldermen came back to the Huſtings, the Sheriffs ſit remote one on the right hand and the other on the left, furtheſt from the Lord Mayor, ſo that all the Aldermen ſit nearer to the
Lord Mayor than the Sheriffs do; did you mind that the Sheriffs came to you to ſpeak to you any thing of an Adjournment?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: I never ſaw it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: I would ask you a Queſtion or two, you know this Gentleman, don't you?pointing to the Common Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Did he attend the Court at that time?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Sir Robert, I ask you a fair queſtion, did you lay any command on him to adjourn the Hall at that time from Saturday till Monday.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: Pray my Lord give me leave to anſwer Mr. Jones in my own way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: My Lord I am in your judgment, it is a fair queſtion within his own Recognizance lately done, he ought to anſwer poſitively Yes or No.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: Am not I upon my Oath, can you tell me what I can ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Ay or no, any honeſt man wou'd do it.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: All Witneſſes anſwer their own way, don't they?

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Let him anſwer then his own way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. General.
sp.p: My Lord, you know there is a rule in Chancery, if it be a matter within ſeven years, if it be not anſwered poſitively it is no anſwer; if one asks a Witneſs a queſtion that lies within a little while, if he will not anſwer either affirmatively or negatively, he is no Witneſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I can't tell, Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Will you anſwer or no Sir Robert Clayton, whether you commanded the Common Serjeant to go and adjourn the Hall or no?

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: I don't remember that I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Then I only ask you this further queſtion, whether Mr. Common Serjeant did not tell you that it was not his proper buſineſs to do it, and that unleſs you would lay expreſs Commands upon him, and put the very words in his mouth, he did deſire to be excuſed, and did he not ſtand there?pointing to the Bar.

sp.speaker: Sir R. Clayton.
sp.p: I have heard, Sir, what Mr. Common Serjeant did ſay, and I cannot charge my memory with it, but I have that charity for Mr. Common Serjeant to believe there might be diſcourſe to that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: Mr. Love, in all your experience what do you remember?

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: How long have you known Guild-hall and Elections?

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p:
I ſuppoſe, my Lord, theſe Gentlemen don't expect I ſhould ſay any thing that was done that day; but, my Lord, all that I ſuppoſe you expect from me is what I did obſerve to be the practice of the City; to the beſt of my remembrance I ſhall give you an account. My Lord, about 22 years ago, I did obſerve the practice to be this, when I was call'd into this Office of Sheriff, I took it as a thing for granted, that it was the Sheriffs Office to manage the Common Hall, that I did, as my Lord Mayor's was to have a Sword born before him; I have received it by tradition from all before me, and my own experience. My Lord, I remember when we came to chuſe Sheriffs upon Midſomer day, after the Lord Mayor and Aldermen had been there, my Lord Mayor ſaid to me and my Brother Sheriff, Gentlemen, look to your Office; we accordingly went to it and choſe two Sheriffs, one Gentleman that had been drank to by my Lord Mayor, I think
it was Alderman 〈◊〉 but notwithſtanding that drinking to him, we took no notice of that as a ceremony, he was put in nomination among others, and being a ſenior ſitting Alderman, we returned him; otherwiſe, my Lord, I aſſure you I would not have returned him notwithſtanding the drinking. After once that the Lord Mayor and Aldermen withdrew to go to the Council Chamber, they ſaid to us, Now Gentlemen, look to your Office.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon,
sp.p: What was your Office?

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: To chuſe Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: Did my Lord Mayor meddle with the election, or left it to the Sheriffs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: Left it to the Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What was your opinion, Sir, was it in the Lord Mayor to take the Poll, or the Sheriffs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: Truly Sir, I am not a competent Judge of whoſe right it was, but if my Lord Mayor had gone about to meddle in it, I ſhould have prayed my Lord Mayor to meddle in his own Office and let me alone with mine.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorney.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Love, you were then the Tribunes of the People.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: Here are ſome ſay the Common Serjeant and the Common Cryer have a power, nay, the whole power of ordering the Hall during the Election. What is the Office of the Common Serjeant there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I look upon the Common Serjeant and the Common Cryer as Perſons left to aſſiſt us, becauſe they would not put us to the trouble of crying O Yes our ſelves; and if any Common Serjeant or Common Cryer had durſt to put a queſtion without my direction, I would have known whether he could or no.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: Mr. Love was it ever dicours'd to you when you were Sheriff, or before or ſince, that ever my Lord Mayor did interpoſe before the Election was over?

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: Since I was diſcharged of being a Magiſtrate, I never was at a Common Hall ſince. I have ſpent my Money for the Cities ſervice, but never got a peny by them; I never heard that ever the Lord Mayor till theſe late times interpoſed, but that the Sheriffs managed the whole buſineſs of chuſing Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Love, I deſire to have a word with you, you ſpeak of the time of your reign, I would ask you a plain queſtion, was it before the King came in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: It was that year the King came in.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was you choſen before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember an Act of Parliament in 48, then in force, of ſhutting out my Lord Mayor?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: I would ask him a queſtion or two. Hark you, Mr. Love, let me ask you a queſtion or two.

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: Sir George, I would give Mr. Attorney an anſwer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What would you make of it? if you ask him of an Act of Parliament it is ſomething.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You ſpeak of a time when my Lord Mayor had no more to do with it than I had. There was an Ordinance of Parliament, did you never ſee that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: To the beſt of my remembrance I never ſaw it in my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Nor heard of ſuch a thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Hark you, Mr. Love, I perceive you would have diſputed with my Lord Mayor, who was the Lord Mayor that you talk of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Allen.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Now I would deſire to know whether you remember the City before the King came in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: For a little while.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Do you remember any thing of that cuſtom of the Lord Mayor's drinking to Sheriffs, was not that uſed before the King came in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Love.
sp.p: A long time.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: It is well enough; a long time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: My Lord, we have ſeven or eight more to the ſame purpoſe, but we are ſatisfied with theſe Gentlemen: we will prove if there was any thing like a Riot, we will prove my Lord Mayor and thoſe that were with him were the Authors of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When multitudes of people are gather'd together upon a lawful occaſion, ſuppoſing that they had a right to be there, I do ſay that in that caſe it would be much a mitigation of the fine, ſo for this ſame riot; but on the other ſide you muſt know that theſe men that do it, it doth not excuſe them, for ignorantia juris is not an excuſe. It is true, if they had had a lawful occaſion to continue to do it, but in truth they had not, that will excuſe them à tanto, but non à toto.

sp.speaker: Mr. Holt.
sp.p: My Lord, I beg to put in this caſe, there is a great deal of difference where a perſon does claim a right to himſelf, and does an extravagant action. Now my Lord theſe perſons did claim a right to themſelves to continue the Common Hall, and that it was not in my Lord Mayor's power to adjourn it without them: now, my Lord, they claimed this right, if they uſed no violence, that is excuſable. If I ſhould claim a right to another man's eſtate, though I have no Title, and ſay I have a right, and give it out in ſpeeches, no action lies againſt me; but if I do an extravagant action, and ſay another man hath a title, there lies an action againſt me.

sp.speaker: L.C. J.
sp.p: Now go to your fact.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: My Lord put a point to us, and we need not call more Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I don't ſpeak to hinder you from calling your Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: I put this caſe, we undertake to prove that it was always looked upon, that it was the right of the Sheriffs: ſuppoſe, my Lord, upon the diſpute it ſhould be found that the opinion of the Jury ſhould be otherwiſe, will this turn to an illegal act?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call your Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: I beſeech your Lordſhip I may put one caſe in this point, in a point of right if they have a probable cauſe to inſiſt upon it. Suppoſe I ſend 40 men to a wood, and take a Carr or a Team, if they be a competent number to cut down wood, if we are miſtaken in the title, that is no Riot. Lambert puts the caſe.

sp.speaker: L.C.J.
sp.p: But what if I had ſent a great many men to cut down the whole Wood?

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: We will call ſome Witneſſes that will take us off from the Riot thus, if ſo be we can excuſe our ſelves of the diſorder, and put it upon my Lord Mayor, then we are innocent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Very well if you do that.

sp.speaker: Mr. 〈◊〉
sp.p: Mr. Sibley, are you acquainted with the manner of the Election of Sheriffs, how long have you known it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: I have been of the Livery ever ſince 39, in all my time, I ſpeak Gentlemen, to the beſt of my remembrance, it hath been the cuſtom in all my time, except here of late, that the Sheriffs of London have had the management of the Election.

sp.speaker: Mr. 〈◊〉
sp.p: Did my Lord Mayor ever interpoſe till the Election was over?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: I never knew my Lord Mayor interpoſe till lately.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: Did you ever hear my Lord Mayor pretend to it till of late?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: Did the Mayor uſe to be preſent at any Election during the Election?

sp.speaker: Mr Sibley.
sp.p: I have been moſt commonly there.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: But the Mayor, would the Mayor be there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: The Mayor and Aldermen went off the Bench.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: Who managed the Elections?

sp.speaker: Mr Sibley.
sp.p: The Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: Were the Common Serjeant and the Common Cryer there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: The Common Serjeant and the Common Cryer are always there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I pray thus, you have known the City it ſeems a great while, I would ask you this, pray who did call the Aſſembly that was to chuſe the Sheriffs, did the Sheriffs or the Lord Mayor?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: We commonly received the Tickets by the Officers of the Companies.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did the Officers of the Companies ſummon the Aſſembly? Hark you, pray Sir, recollect your ſelf, Do you take it that the Officers, the Beadles it may be of the ſeveral Companies, did they ſummon the Livery-men, and ſo a Common Hall was call'd together, was it ſo in your time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: It hath been commonly ſo, we have received Tickets from the Beadle of the Company.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And my Lord Mayor had nothing to do with it then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: What order the Maſters and Wardens had from my Lord Mayor, I never inquired into that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When the Hall was diſſolved, who ordered Proclamation to be made, the Sheriffs or the Lord Mayor?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: My Lord Mayor hath not uſed to be there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon
sp.p: When they had done, they went away. He won't trouble your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray had my Lord any hand in ſummoning, did he direct the ſummoning of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: It is more than I know.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You bring a Witneſs that knows nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Mr. Deputy Sibley. Give me leave to ask Mr. Sibley a queſtion or two, I ſhall ſet him to rights preſently. Mr. Sibley, if I be not miſtaken you are one of the Company of Tallow-Chandlers, and you have been Maſter of the Company, and you have been Warden of the Company. You very well know what directions are given to the Beadle are generally by the Maſter or Wardens, pray upon your Oath when you were Maſter or Warden, was there ever any Precept ſent to you to ſummon a Common Hall?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: Indeed I don't remember that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: If your Lordſhip pleaſe, we have done with our evidence, I would beg your Lordſhips opinion in it.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: We do admit, my Lord Mayor ſummons the Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you bring a Witneſs that knows nothing in the world of it, but yet you would have it taken for Goſpel, that the Sheriffs had all the management before that time 40 years together, till now very lately. But when he comes to be asked how is this Aſſembly or Common Hall call'd together, alas! he knows no more of that than one in Utopia.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: My Lord, we have ſeveral other Witneſſes, but we will call no more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: If you have no more, we will call two or three more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: We have ſome to prove that my Lord Grey, came to ſpeak with Sir William Gulſton, and went away again, and we deſire to call Sir Thomas Armſtrong.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: My Lord, if your Lordſhip pleaſes, thus, there will be it ſeems ſome particular defences made. Your Lordſhip hath heard their evidence, and what we have ſaid; we deſire to call two or three Witneſſes to another head. Your Lordſhip hath heard there was ſome rudeneſs by ſome of the people, but who they were it doth not appear. We will call two or three Witneſſes of the behaviour thoſe men and Company that came with my Lord Mayor, that whatſoever diſturbance was made, they were the chief men that made the diſturbance, and my Lord Mayor could not help it, nor we neither.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Sir Francis, I believe thoſe men that would not have God ſave the King, my Lord Mayor could not hinder them, but will you undertake to prove that thoſe that came with my Lord Mayor, that they were the men.

sp.speaker: Sir F. Winnington.
sp.p: They were with them, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: They were with them that cryed God bleſs the Proteſtant Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sibley.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to explain my ſelf to what I ſaid; it is ſeveral years agoe ſince I was Maſter of the Company, I do not remember, but I believe the Summons was directed from my Lord Mayor.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freak.
sp.p: Mr. Winſtanley, what account can you give to my Lord and the Jury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: I have lived near the Hall, and I often came in, but I was not a Livery man upon that Poll, that was between Mr. Kiffen and Sir Robert Clayton; the Sheriffs managed it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freak.
sp.p: Who managed it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: The Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freak,
sp.p: Who declared?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: The Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freak.
sp.p: Did the Mayor come down to declare the Election?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: The Mayor came down after the Poll, but the Sheriffs took the Poll.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freak.
sp.p: Who was then Mayor?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: Sir James Edwards was Sheriff, and Sir John Smith.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freak.
sp.p: Who was Mayor?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: It was Sir Samuel Starling.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freak.
sp.p: Who put the Queſtion upon the Huſtings?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freak.
sp.p: What did you hear the Sheriffs ſay or ſee them do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: The Sheriffs preſently granted a Poll, and parted one to one door, and the other to t'other.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freak.
sp.p: And who took the Poll?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: The Sheriffs took it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freak.
sp.p: Who declared the Election?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: The Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freak.
sp.p: Who were Sheriffs then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winstanley.
sp.p: Sir James Edwards and Sir John Smith.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Mr. Winſtanley, I would ask you this queſtion, do you take it upon your oath that the Sheriffs declared the Election?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: I declare upon my oath that the Sheriffs took the Poll.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Mr. Winſtanley, you may gueſs pretty well what I mean by this. Firſt of all, I ask you, did the Sheriffs put the queſtion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: The Sheriffs took the Poll, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Nay, anſwer my queſtion, did the Sheriffs put the queſtion, or did any body elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: Truly Sir, I have forgot, you were there.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: I know I was Sir, I know very well, I ask you upon your oath, who was it that declared the Election afterwards? upon your oath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: Truly, Sir George, I don't remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Mr. Winſtanley, one went out at one door you ſay, and t'other went out at t'other, you ſay; now I ſay who took notice, and told the names of thoſe that went out at one door and t'other?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: The two Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Who elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Jefferies.
sp.p: Do you remember me there at the great Door, when they poll'd and went out, do you remember who told them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: No truly.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Pray, do you remember when one Mr. Broom a Wax-chandler was choſen Ale-conner?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: I was in the Hall, but I do not charge my Memory with it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Hark you, Mr. Winſtanley, who is it grants the Poll when it is demanded?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: I do remember very well Sr. George Jefferies was in the Hall, they demanded a Poll and ſo went out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Who granted it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: The two Sheriffs.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: I will put you a Caſe nearer home, Mr. Winſtanley, you remember when Sir Thomas Player was choſen Chamberlain, when the Queſtion was put, Who ſhould be Chamberlain, between him and a Gentleman, I ſee not far from me, who do you remember managed the Poll then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: There was no need Sir George.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you mean to do with theſe little Witneſſes? you call Witneſſes that know nothing of the matter, or nothing to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: My Lord, let me ask him but one Queſtion more, I know he hath been a very great Evidence in this Caſe, I remember when that Gentleman was in for Bridge-maſter, Who was the Poll demanded of at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſtanley.
sp.p: Truly Sir, I think it was demanded of the Court.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jefferies.
sp.p: Of the Court?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſt.
sp.p: Uſually upon other Days my Lord Mayor and the Court come down, but upon Midſummer-day they go up.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jeff.
sp.p: But I ask you of whom the Poll was demanded at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Winſt.
sp.p: I Don't remember it I'le aſſure you.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You told us that point would be granted, and you would not ſtand upon it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: My Lord, where there are ſo many men, there may be many Minds, I would have your Lordſhip and the Jury hear them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: The Government is concerned, Mr. Williams.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Jeff.
sp.p: This is not a matter of Mirth I'le aſſure you, it reaches the Government.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: My Lord Mayor hath the power of adjourning the Hall, but not till the Buſineſs is done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I would put you a Caſe Here Mr. Jones offered to interrupt him. —Sure, Mr. Jones I ought to be heard. If my Lord Mayor hath power to call a Common-hall, he hath not to adjourn it before the Buſineſs is done.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If a Writ come to the Sheriffs to chooſe Parliament men, then the Sheriffs have it, but this is my Lord Mayors Office, he hath power to diſſolve and adjourn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomſon.
sp.p:
I ſpeak to this Caſe, my Lord, I will ſhew your Lordſhip an inſtance where it cannot be done. My Lord Mayor hath power to call here, and he hath power to diſſolve, ſay they: My Lord, it cannot be, with ſubmiſſion, in all Caſes. He hath power to call an Aſſembly when
there is a Mayor to be choſen, and the Citizens have a Priviledge to move their Mayor or continue him, now if it were in the power of the Mayor, and there ſhould happen a queſtion who they were for in a great Number of Electors, if it were in his power to adjourn from time to time, he muſt continue Mayor.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It is plain he may do it for all your Objection.
